definition: to set out (of troops)/departure/start date (of military expedition)

to open/to start/to turn on/to boil/to write out (a prescription, check, invoice etc)/to operate (a vehicle)/carat (gold)/abbr. for Kelvin, 開爾文|开尔文[Kai1 er3 wen2]/abbr. for 開本|开本[kai1 ben3], book format
to pull up/to pull out/to draw out by suction/to select/to pick/to stand out (above level)/to surpass/to seize

sentences.english: The troops are ready to move out at short notice.
sentences.chinese: 部队准备一接到命令就开拔。

sentences.english: With its cloud of skirmishers in advance.
sentences.chinese: 兵卷残云提前开拔军营。

sentences.english: You will bide here until we are ready to march.
sentences.chinese: 你驻留在这里知道我们准备开拔。

sentences.english: The order from the commander was that the troops should set off for the front immediately.
sentences.chinese: 司令官的命令是部队立即开拔去前线。

sentences.english: Troops are moving up to the combat zone.
He'll sail from the harbor tomorrow morning.
sentences.chinese: 翌早上他将从港口开拔起航。

definition: (of troops) to depart for/to head for
to go on a journey/to leave
to dress (troops)/to line up (to arrange in a straight line)
to set out on a journey
to camp/to pitch camp/stationed/quartered/Taiwan pr. [zha2 ying2]
